_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Cavendish Farms facility, located in Jamestown, North Dakota, is a potato processing facility 
that uses pure anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant. The primary purpose of the facility is to 
process potatoes into food products such as French fries for distribution to retailers and 
restaurants.

Ammonia is classified by the EPA as a toxic chemical, and it is necessary to observe certain safety 
precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the health threat to 
our workers and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to 
adhere to all Federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon a combination of how we handle ammonia, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the 
safe handling procedures that we use, and the training of our personnel.

We have a written Process Safety Management (PSM) plan in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119. A 
crucial component of this plan is the Emergency Response Plan, developed in compliance with the 
Emergency Response provisions of 29 CFR 1910.120.

1.10 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
An accidental release prevention program has been in place since the start-up of the existing 
facility in 1996. The facility was constructed using the International Institute of Ammonia 
Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and complies with state codes.
All of our ammonia refrigeration operators are trained using on-the-job training and a formal 
training program. This program consists of having an effective preventative maintenance program and comprehensive employee training to ensure adequate response to equipment integrity.

The process has numerous safeguards, including:
-Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.
-Most of the lines are elevated to minimize potential damage from forklifts.
-The Plant has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident o

r incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.
A process hazard analysis (PHA) re-validation was conducted in September 2024. A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system. The PHA addressed: (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of the control system failures.
1.20 Facility Description and Substances Handled
The regulated substance handled at the facility is anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous ammonia is used to refrigerate areas of the facility where food products are processed and/or stored. The refrigeration equipment compresses, condenses, and evaporates ammonia in a closed-loop system to remove heat from areas within the facility.

1.30 The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including 
administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.
Release scenarios were modeled using RMP*Comp, a software program developed by the 
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and EPA. Offsite receptors were defined 
using ArcGIS Pro 3.4.2 in conjunction with Google Maps. This system estimates the residential 
population within the circle defined by the endpoint of the worst-case and alternative release 
scenarios. In addition, it lists whether certain types of public receptors and environmental 
receptors are within the circles.

1.40 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
Cavendish Farms complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable 
state codes and regulations. The design and construction of this facility were in

accordance with
published standards, tests, or recommended methods of trade, industry, or governmental organizations.
Cavendish Farms' written PSM plan incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure the safe 
operation and maintenance of this facility. Plan elements essential to the safe operation of the 
refrigeration system include employee participation, process hazard information, process hazard 
analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical 
integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits. This plan will be reviewed periodically and updated as necessary.
Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for the proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.
For projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to 
ensure that system changes or expansions are safe and that the changes are consistent with the 
engineering design and in condition to be operated before startup.
Contractors that are used to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" 
based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and 
standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely. Each of these contractors is evaluated 
from a safety perspective.
The Plant has a program for the replacement of all Safety Relief Valves on a 5-year interval as 
recommended by IIAR.

1.50 Five-Year Accident History
There has been no significant release of ammonia at Cavendish Farms in the past five years that has resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on-site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

1.60 Emergency Response Progra

m
Our emergency response program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility. The 
emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local 
emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility 
emergency response plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements. The 
emergency response plan has been discussed with the Jamestown Fire Department and other agencies involved with the response. Representatives of the Jamestown Fire Department visit this plant on an annual basis.
The facility has a trained team of emergency responders who are available to minimize any ammonia release. These trained staff are skilled at responding to a release and isolating problem areas within the ammonia refrigeration system.

1.70 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Any upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will comply with those standards applicable at that time. Cavendish Farms identified recommendations to improve safety during the most recent compliance audit in October 2022. These recommendations are scheduled to be completed by June 2027.
